results.title: Dinosaurs: the terrible lizards
results.creator_credit: Wah Chang and Charles Cahill and Associates
results.brief_description: Uses special effects and models to recreate the age of the dinosaurs. Gives an overview of what they looked like, what they ate, and how they lived and died. Suitable for lower and upper primary levels.

results.title: Dinosaurs: the age of the terrible lizard
results.brief_description: An animated film which presents an overview of the dinosaur age, showing the major types of dinasaurs and some of their behavioural characteristics. Gives evidence of evolutionary development and indicates a possible reason for their becoming extinct. Edited version of film “Dinozaury”.

results.title: Dinosaurs: fun, facts and fantasy
results.creator_credit: Malcolm Craddock, Clive Doig and Picture Palace Productions
results.brief_description: This informative and entertaining program is a mixture of puppets, songs, animated models, drawings, old film footage and dramatised sequences, and it will answer everything you ever wanted to know about dinosaurs.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Malcolm Craddock, Clive Doig and Picture Palace Productions

results.title: Dinosaurs
results.creator_credit: Steve Skok, Curriculum Branch, Ministry of Ed, Schools Div, Victoria and Peter Bence
results.brief_description: Fossil records show that the dinosaurs were an enormously successful group containing many species. This program examines the reasons why they were so prolific and discusses some of the theories behind their disappearance.

results.title: Dinosaur tracks
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Johnson and friends”.
Johnson and his friends get together in six stories. In “Diesel tries to fly” all the toys are put in danger as Diesal tries out his wings. Squeaky’s good at guarding the bedroom but what about the “Dinosaur tracks”? Is Johnson falling apart as the toys follow the mysterious “Pink thread.” “Melissa’s dinosaur”, Victoria is introduced to the toys. In “Diesel who?”, the toy loses his memory after a nasty crash. McDuff feels very superior after a visit to the toyshop, and the toys try to get her back to her old self in The Homecoming.

results.title: Dinosaur junction series
results.brief_description: This video contains three short episodes of ‘Dinosaur Junction’ which uses animated dinosaurs to illustrate in a fun way how children can learn to cope with problems they face such as peer pressure and fighting. ‘Doin’ it you way’ looks at decision making and peer pressure; ‘The fight’ looks at controlling your temper and dealing with anger; ‘What’s in a name’ looks at self esteem and fitting in. Suitable for Primary level students.

results.title: Dinosaur
results.creator_credit: Pam Marsden, Walt Disney Pictures, Eric Leighton and Ralph Zondag
results.brief_description: Lavish Disney family movie, “Dinosaur” broke new ground with its awe-inspiring aesthetics of computer animation, set against live action backgrounds. The simplistic story is pure Disney - Aladar is an iguanodon snatched by a pterodactyl whilst still in the egg; the egg, via a range of predators and mishaps, makes a treacherous journey across land and sea until a clan of lemurs adopt the baby as one of their own; when a meteor shower rattles the inhabitants of the continent, they decide to flee; en route, Aladar experiences life with his own kind for the first time. The film entertains a gentle, traditional family brand of humour that supports the themes of compassion, friendship and tolerance with a gentle nod toward respecting one’s elders. The predictable narrative progression, a conventional quest that supports a basic morality of good triumphing over evil, is overcome by the impressive animation and stupendous set pieces.

results.title: Dinosaur
results.creator_credit: Pam Marsden, Walt Disney Pictures, Ralph Zondag and Eric Leighton
results.brief_description: Computer animated feature from Walt Disney Pictures, artfully combined live action backgrounds with CGI pre-historic beasts. This family oriented adventure movie is about an orphaned dinosaur raised by lemurs. Years later when the inhabitants flee the continent, Aladar, as he is known, encounters his own kind for the first time. The landmark animation of this feature was highly praised for its attention to detail and awe-inspiring aesthetics. Features the voices of D.B. Sweeney, Alfre Woodard, Ossie Davis, Max Casella, Hayden Panettiere, and Sam Wright.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Pam Marsden, Walt Disney Pictures, Ralph Zondag and Eric Leighton

results.title: Dinosaur
results.creator_credit: Will Vinton and Will Vinton Productions
results.brief_description: Clay animated figures and simple chalk line drawings are transformed into awe-inspiring prehistoric animals in this interpretation of our earth as it existed long before man. A fastpaced motivating introduction to dinosaurs and their prehistoric world, suitable for children of all ages.

results.title: Dinner for two
results.creator_credit: Barrie Angus McLean, ONF | NFB and Janet Perlman
results.brief_description: Peace in the rainforest is disrupted when two chameleons get “stuck” in a conflict, with catastrophic results. Luckily for the lizards, a frog observing the fracas turns into exactly what they need…(no, not a prince)…a mediator. “Dinner for two” tackles conflict in lively, humorous and provocative ways. It shows that amidst the chaos that differences create, there are still paths to reconcilliation. This animated film without words is designed as a flexible tool to explore conflict resolution. Young children to senior executives can identify with the characters, and gain an insight into how to deal creatively with conflict and anger at school, at home, in the workplace and in their communities.
